Share the Indiegogo link or even www.rockcityposters.com link with your friends on Twitter, Facebook and Instagram. Do it daily. Talk about it at the bar. Maybe one of your friends has a couple extra bucks they'd be able to throw at the fundraising. You can single handedly bombard all the social media sites with this link and the video. Indiegogo has several share tools that make it easy.And that’s all there is to it. Thank you for helping to make this great idea a reality. One person can't do it alone, that's why I ask you for help. This is our town, our music and art scene, and this gallery is built by us for us. Just like 7Seconds wrote it..."If we can walk together, why can't we rock together?"

story:
Think of this campaign just like a public television pledge drive. The great news is we're only doing it once. We are asking for one time donations to help us make Chapter2books a bigger and better store.

If you don't live nearby, we are asking for your support because you value independent bookstores and local business. We have great perks at every donation level. If you live in Hudson and the St Croix Valley, we need your support at any giving level and we will make it worth your while.

We are raising funds for the following reasons:

We were forced to leave our prime spot on Hudson's main street, 2nd St, due to a change in ownership.

We need to add signage to our new building at 226 Locust St as soon as possible.

We would like to advertise in Hudson and surrounding communities.

Brian and I run the store on our own.

In the future we would love to hire staff. Your donation would help us hire at least 2 paid interns this summer. Their tasks would include marketing, help with outreach to schools etc.

Our extended winters are tough on retail.

I'm not telling you anything you don't already know but the fact that we moved in March made it extra tough. 

Some things you may not know:

Unlike other types of retail, we are bound by publisher's set prices. We can mark down, but not up. We do have sales as much as possible. The stronger the business is, the more we can pass the savings on to you with discounts.

We would like to offer online shopping.

There are administrative costs involved that we can't take on right now. The stronger we get, the better we'll be able to serve Hudson, Western Wisconsin, and the St Croix Valley.

We do offer E Readers and E book downloads through Kobo.

Kobo e readers can read books originally purchased through Nook and Kindle.

We know Amazon is considered to be cheap and convenient.

We hope that you will consider the fact that cheap is not cheap. Everyone benefits from having an independent bookstore in Hudson.

What we give in return:

Participation in town events

Donations to local fundraisers

We pay local taxes

Partnerships with other businesses

We bring authors to town who bring spouses and friends who shop all over Hudson

Discounts and other perks for schools and book clubs etc

Support for local authors

We can help you pick out just the right gift

We know and stock books that Hudson residents are reading

We have friendly, sincere, I would say: excellent customer service

We can encourage reluctant readers to pick out a book and read

We have weekly story time

We have Family Fun Nights, Super Reader Club and birthday benefits

We host book clubs

We read daily book blogs, attend trade shows and keep up with what your next great read can be


We need signs outside as soon as possible.

We would love to enhance our seating area with a fireplace like this one so that we can be a great community meeting space in Hudson.


Super Reader Capes are among the many great perks we have available for your donations.

story:
Our Story

The Edible Edmund Alley will be a mini-forest garden planted along an alley in a high-traffic area of St. Paul. Native fruit trees and shrubs such as juneberries, wild plums, and currants will be planted on this parcel. As the garden grows it will become a site for foraging workshops, as well as a source of free fruit for the community.

The project is organized by the North Country Food Alliance, a food justice nonprofit based in the Twin Cities. As part of its mission, North Country Food Alliance builds gardens in urban areas, giving residents the opportunity to gain hands-on knowledge of the gardening process. The produce from these gardens is donated to organizations that serve low-income people, such as soup kitchens and homeless shelters.

North Country Food Alliance also holds urban foraging workshops in the Twin Cities. These donation-based workshops teach participants how to safely gather wild foods growing in St. Paul and Minneapolis, empowering people to pick fresh, healthy foods for free in their own neighborhoods.

The Edible Edmund Alley is the perfect synthesis of our garden and foraging programs, providing a resource that will demonstrate how to build and maintain a forest garden, teach how to identify and harvest wild foods, and grant free fruits to low-income people. 

The Impact

Hamline-Midway (the site of the Edible Edmund Alley) is a low-income neighborhood. More immediately, directly southeast of the site is Kimball Court, a multi-story low-income apartment building. This garden will serve the needs of the community by:
  • Providing free educational opportunities to get involved in the process of planting and maintaining fruit trees and perennials.
  • Offering donation-based foraging workshops that explain how to identify, harvest, and prepare wild foods.
  • Creating a location where passersby will be free to pick the edibles. 
  • Donating fruits to the Keystone Community Food Shelf based in the neighborhood.


What We Need

North Country Food Alliance is a small nonprofit that runs on a tight budget. We need this funding primarily to clear the parcel of unwanted trees and shrubs. Estimates to clear the site, including stump grinding to prevent regrowth and create more usable soil, have been around $800. The remaining $200 will go toward equipment and tools to maintain the garden, as well as fruit trees and shrubs to be planted there.


Other Ways You Can Help

Even a small donation will help us reach our goal! However, if you can't donate financially, please consider helping by:

  • Sharing this campaign with friends, family, neighbors, or co-workers.
  • Using the social media buttons on your left to share this campaign on Facebook, Twittter, your website, etc.
  • Donating your time! If you live in the Twin Cities area, sign up to volunteer on our website.

Thank you!

story:
The PBJ-1J Restoration:

Have you ever wanted to feel like you've done something truly amazing? Today is your chance to donate to help finish this beautiful PBJ Mitchell World War II aircraft.

  • The PBJ is an American World War II aircraft thats primary purpose was to bomb targets.
  • This is one of the last PBJ planes that survived the war, so this is a once in a lifetime opportunity.
  • The electronic components are the final pieces to our puzzle!
  • With your help we can get this bird off the ground and back in the sky!

What we need to raise money for:

  • Currently we are raising money for electronic components for the plane. 
  • With your donations we can offer rewards based on amount of money donated.
  • If we do not reach our $1000 goal the money will STILL be donated to the SoCal Commerative Air force, located in Camarillo, CA.

Want to learn & know more about the plane & the CAF?

Visit the Commemorative Air Force's website to learn more about who they are and what they represent! 
https://www.cafsocal.com

Visit the website below if you're curious about the plane's background and history!
http://www.skytamer.com/North_American_PBJ-1J.html

story:
Kreativ kriminalomsorg

Igjen er Vardeteatret på bar bakke, mens Norge bruker 242 mill. på fengselsplasser i Nederland skriver Harriet Eide i Dagbladet.

  • Vardeteateret har jobbet med teater som et verktøy for folk på vei ut av fengsel.
  • Siden 2003 har vel 60 straffedømte skapt seg et nytt liv etter soning gjennom Vardeteateret.
  • En fengselsplass koster fra 400.000,- til over 1.080.000,-,  til prisen av to - tre fengselsplasser hadde Vardeteateret  drift vært sikret.

Nå er Vardeteatret igjen på bar bakke. Det mangler 350.000,- kroner i inneværende år for å fullføre en ny forestilling, «Fengselsfuglene». i samarbeid med Foreningen for fangers pårørende. Planlagt premiere 27. oktober. Men hvor? Teatret har midler til 15. november.?

Hva vi trenger

Vi trenger å sikre finansieringen:

  • Derfor ber vi om en kronerulling av 115.000,- (12.000,- Euro) her.
  • Vi byr på liv og teater, og møte med mennesker med historier å fortelle.
  • Ditt bidrag gjør at Vardeteateret får muskler til å kjempe videre

Folkene bak

Jo Skjønberg og Leif Sørensen har drevet Vardeteateret siden 2003. Vardeteateret har årlig sloss for å gi straffedømte en livmesteringserfaring gjennom teater etter soning.  I tillegg har Vardeteateret drevet et tilsvarende prosjekt i Cape Town i Sør-Afrika  - help I am free  -  Vardeteateret sitt arbeid er god samfunnøkonomi, her er en etterprøvd metode:
  • Vi gir folk verktøy til å lære ny livsmestering.
  • Vi reduserer antallet folk med tilbakefall til kriminalitet
  • Vi løfter fram andre historier, fortalt av folk som har levd et annet liv

Hjelp oss til å skape en framtid


Pengene vi samler inn gjennom denne kronerullingen vil gå til å produsere forestillinger. Å bidra med penger her gir deg trygghet for at vi kan fortsette med vårt arbeid.  For å bidra med alt fra 150.- til 5000,-  må du ha en PayPal konto, det er enkelt å opprette her.

  • PayPal er en verdens mest brukt betalingsformidlingstjenester
  • Løsningen er sikker og underlagt norsk finanslov.

Har du ikke mulighet til å bruke PayPal ta kontakt med e-post: leif@vardeteatret.org 

Del og fortell om oss

Skal vi lykkes med denne kronerullingen trenger vi din hjelp:
  • Ta en kamp for en annen kriminalpolitikk, spre informasjon om oss.
  • Del denne kampanjen med vennene dine på facebook, twitter og epost

Hvis mange nok står sammen med oss, vil vi lykkes.

story:
If you are a close friend or family, you remember the time in 2011 when my mother and I won the Tamale making contest in San Diego (full story). If you've known me for a while, you remember when I co-owned a catering/personal chef business in San Diego. Whenever I look back to times I was the happiest, both of those snapshots of my life come to mind immediately.   

Now, lest you be thinking that I'm just that starry-eyed bartender with one dish and zero clue how to run a restaurant, I did books/mgmt consulting for Bety's Tacos in SD. From 2006-2008 and managed two high volume fine-casual dining spots in SD In 2011 opened up the new chain of cafes in SF, all while bartending at multiple dive bars in my neighborhood. That's a decade of HANDS ON experience.
And on Aug 17th 2015, I get the keys to my own brick and mortar restaurant.
That's right, I don't need help procuring or buying my own place. Through careful negotiations and being presented an opportunity I just couldn't pass-up, I'll be in business for myself come next month.  
Opening my own place was one of my stated purposes for moving to SF.
And here's where you come in!
With the help of some bare-minimum operating funds I can get:
-A POS system (point of sale)—we plan to go paperless with a  Square card reader and an ipad or iphone) which we'll buy used
-paint to splash on the walls
-decorations, art and signage
- kitchenware including a vertical broiler and a deep fryer (for those fish tacos!) 
-And rest will go to buying the first month's worth of ingredients for the menu... 
The menu:
I have two local chefs consulting and helping me construct and finalize my menu for the grand opening in September. It is going to be seasonal, New American with, what I know best: a SoCal Mexican leaning.  Hence,"Chicáno Nuevo." And of course, all as organic and local ingredients as we can find.
For SF people, think of NoPa, ALTA CA, Central Kitchen, then think of my tamale pop-up happening at a tequila/mezcal cantina in Bernal Heights SF, and our menu will land somewhere near the lower half  of the cantina. For now. 
I have been lucky enough to take this exhilarating first step. In order to keep moving forward to a great opening and beyond, I am going to need you. 
So, taking a cue from the millennial generation, here I stand humbly asking for your help in achieving a life goal with me :)
Thanks. 
Abraham Nuñez!
415 583 7641

story:
SUPPORT US

Help our NGO organization (an organization no profit focused on culture with the social mission to "improve the face of the city", and to safeguard animals right)
to face the disaster in a transparent and durable way: we will repair in first person and employing only needy local people, critical area of Tbilisi, in a way that overstep the "logic of disaster", and with the aim to lead Tbilisi, for the quality of our interventions, to the levels of the major European cities, both from the point of view of material damages and as for the right of animals.


Aiuta la nostra organizzazione (una organizzazione NGO incentrata sulla cultura con la missione sociale di "migliorare il volto della città" e di salvaguardare i diritti degli animali) ad affrontare il disastro in un modo trasparente e durevole: noi ripareremo in prima persona e impiegando solo persone locali bisognose e meritevoli, aree critiche di Tbilisi in un modo che oltrepassa la "logica del disastro" e con il fine di portare Tbilisi, per la qualità dei nostri interventi, al livello delle maggiori città europee, sia dal punto di vista dei danni materiali, sia riguardo i diritti degli animali.


WE SPECIFICALLY WANT TO HELP TO IMPROVE THOSE
AREAS OF THE CITY INVOLVED IN THE FLOOD, BUT NOT
NECESSARILY NEAR THE TBILISI ZOO, ON WHICH THE
AUTHORITIES ARE ALREADY FOCUSED.

ALSO, WE WANT TO PROPOSE A PLAN TO REDESIGN ZOO
IN WHICH ANIMALS WILL BE ABLE TO INHABIT A PARK
AS THEY WOULD IN THEIR ORIGINAL HABITAT, RATHER
THAN BEING ENCLOSED IN CAGES.

VISITORS CAN CROSS THE PARK INSIDE A SAFE CABIN
WHILE ANIMALS ARE FREE TO ROAM.


"Also the eating of meat of other species should be, primarily, “prohibited by law” (which is of course against nature, but the only way by which man could actually be said different from “animals”) and the Institute of italian culture will perform specific initiatives in order to achieve this, which is of course within the reach of the new generations, as well as of the our, if only we get to work in this direction. Nevertheless, the use of meat is not only a “bad habit”, but a crime, in addition to be an a horror of the worst kind − a nightmare, if only we realize it for a moment − and therefore we'll try to move in this direction in a urgent and effective way."

(from our Statute, Appendix)



What We Need & What You Get

    We need the support of all and we'll post a specific page on our site, with all information about the use of money (in a precise and exhaustive way) and relative donors. We wish as many information as possible about our donors since they are a crucial part of the project and possibly we will involve them for further collaboration to better reach our goals.

  Noi abbiamo bisogno del supporto di tutti e inseriremo una pagina specifica sul nostro sito, con tutte le informazioni circa l'utilizzo dei soldi (in un modo preciso e esaustivo) ed i relativi sostenitori. Noi vorremmo quante più informazioni possibile su di loro poiché essi sono una parte cruciale del progetto ed eventualmente noi li coinvolgeremo in una ulteriore collaborazione per meglio raggiungere i nostri obiettivi.


(the image shows a detail in Kolmeorneoba sq., not directly affected by the flood, but requiring necessary restorations as a vital center of the city)

We wish as many information as possible about our donors since they are a crucial part of the project and possibly we will involve them for further collaboration to better reach our goals.
  Noi abbiamo bisogno del supporto di tutti e inseriremo una pagina specifica sul nostro sito, con tutte le informazioni circa l'utilizzo dei soldi (in un modo preciso e esaustivo) ed i relativi sostenitori. Noi vorremmo quante più informazioni possibile su di loro poiché essi sono una parte cruciale del progetto ed eventualmente noi li coinvolgeremo in una ulteriore collaborazione per meglio raggiungere i nostri obiettivi.
(the image shows a detail in Kolmeorneoba sq., not directly affected by the flood, but requiring necessary restorations as a vital center of the city)

story:
What is The Front Porch?

The Front Porch is a 501c3 nonprofit with a desire to create deeper community in Austin, Texas through dialogue. In today's postmodern, technologically dependent world, there seem to be fewer opportunities for folks to simply sit down and talk about what's happening around us. The Front Porch focuses on filling that void in our realities by providing Austin with conversation driven, community focused events each and every month. Often inviting Austin's greatest minds and musicians to spark the initial dialogue, The Front Porch offers a unique, conversational setting in which people of varied perspectives may come together to discuss the things that matter most to us in an open environment where all are welcome.

We're proud of the work we do. Our pub church, Parable, meets monthly in local taverns, and has seen conversations with Texas music legend Ray Benson, Senator Kirk Watson, media mammoth Evan Smith, and writer and film maker Turk Pipkin, just to name few. Our monthly concert experience, Unplugged on The Front Porch, has been host to Mother Falcon, Tish Hinojosa, Sam Baker, and Michael Fracasso in 2014 alone, and will soon close out with a final session with Sara Hickman on December 20th. In response to the growing number of Front Porchers we've seen at our staple programs, we also started a brand new program this year for young people, The Window, which saw appearances from comedian Andy Crouch and rising Austin hip-hop outfit, Magna Carda. We've gathered a lot of momentum and we're ready to keep it going.

As we enter our seventh official season in 2015, we know bigger things are on the horizon. Our first event of the new year will bring Carter Beckworth to The Front Porch for Unplugged on January 15th. Then, just four days later, we will partner with KUT and the Alamo Drafthouse to bring Michael Morton to Austin for our quarterly symposium, Elephant in the Room, for one of our biggest gatherings to date.  Following this incredibly special event, we know we can make our upcoming season our best yet, and that's why we're asking for your help here.

We're asking the Indiegogo community to help us generate even more energy and impact. For $30,000, we can fund the basics for the first half of our 2015 season. That would be HUGE for us.

A nonprofit organization with 501(c)(3) status since 2009, we have worked tirelessly out of our own passion and the generosity of friends to provide the majority of our event costs, which have grown to somewhere near $60,000 a year. Now, we are opening our branches to you folks here at Indiegogo in hopes that you can help us take the next steps in providing quality, community focused programming for Austin and the world around us for years to come. Visit our blog post for this campaign here or our Facebook page to find out more. You can also purchase tickets for our upcoming event with Michael Morton by visiting the Alamo Drafthouse online, or have special seats provided if you pick the right perk!


The Front Porch 2015 Season


Our Symposium

Estimated cost per quarter: $3,000

Designed to raise questions about uncomfortable truths in our reality, Elephant in the Room always packs a serious punch, and our symposium topics have ranged from human trafficking to the lingering effects of war for our returning veterans. Each Elephant in the Room brings an expert lecturer to a local venue to help stir and shape a Front Porch conversation, providing an engaging, community-focused experience for all who attend.

  Author and veteran David W. Peters, Interviewed by John Burnett. November 2014

                                                                                  Elephant in The Room at The Brass House

Monday, January 19th, 2015

The Front Porch Presents: Elephant in the Room with Michael Morton

For our first Elephant in the Room of 2015, we are honored to bring Michael Morton to The Front Porch. Wrongfully incarcerated for nearly 25 years in Texas, Michael will help lead a discussion about where forgiveness can be found in today's version of 21st century justice. We hope that Michael can shed insight on resentment and the racial divide, as well as the ways in which he was able to foster a strong, relationship based community in the depths of a prison system characterized by hatred. Sponsored by both KUT and Alamo Drafthouse, this event will feature an interview, a book signing, a film screening, and a Q&A with Michael in efforts to raise the above questions and more.

Here's the two-part events schedule for Monday, January 19th.

  • Noon: KUT's Ben Philpott interviews Michael in KUT Studios, followed by a signing of his memoir, Getting Life. 
  • 7:00 pm: Alamo Drafthouse Village hosts a screening of An Unreal Dream: The Michael Morton Story, followed by the Q&A.

Here's the trailer for An Unreal Dream: The Michael Morton Story.


More About Michael

 In 1987, Michael Morton was wrongfully convicted of the murder of his wife in a Williamson county court. He spent nearly 25 years in prison and lost his relationship with his son before he was finally exonerated by DNA evidence supporting his innocence, and was released from prison on Oct 4, 2011. Since then he has been a strong voice in holding prosecutors accountable when they cross the line in their pursuit of justice. His memoir, Getting Life , tells his story of tragedy, injustice and forgiveness. The movie, An Unreal Dream: The Michael Morton Story, was a SXSW world premiere and Audience Award winner in 2013.  Bill 1611, the Michael Morton Act, was signed into law, enforcing openness and transparency in Texas’s criminal justice system and helping prevent wrongful convictions.  

 Michael shakes Gov. Perry's hand after he signs Bill 1611, "The Michael Morton Act."

We will host our second Elephant in The Room of 2015 in either March or April, and plan to have Gilbert Tuhabonye for that next discussion, which will center on genocide. While this signature symposium series is a very special part of what The Front Porch has to offer, it is still only one component of our multifaceted programming umbrella. Here are the rest of the events we offer on a monthly or bimonthly basis.


Our Live Music Experience

                                              Mother Falcon, Unplugged on the Front Porch, October 2014

On the third Thursday of each month, The Front Porch partners with Live Music Capital Foundation to produce Unplugged on The Front Porch, our unique concert experience. Focused on intimacy and community, Unplugged on The Front Porch features a top Austin artist or band playing two musical sets that sandwich an interview with our executive director, Stephen Kinney. The interview helps foster that dialogue that we're always talking about, and sometimes the musicians will have a drink with our audience at intermission to keep that conversation alive.

The concert always takes place in the sanctuary at All Saints' Episcopal Church, and it's hard to imagine a space more intimate to venerate the amazing musicians who join us each month. We get the best talent in Austin because we pay our artists a living wage, no matter what, and provide them with a respectful audience and state-of-the-art sound production. Each Unplugged on the Front Porch event is also video taped by LMCF. We hope that they will have the 2014 season ready for your viewing pleasure in the next month or two.

Here's a clip of Jimmie Dale Gilmore and Colin Gilmore from last season.


Other Past Artists Featured by Unplugged on The Front Porch:  Mother Falcon, Tish Hinojosa, Sam Baker, Nelo, Darden Smith, Will Taylor and Strings Attached with John Pointer, Michael Fracasso, Terri Hendrix and Lloyd Maines, Ruby Jane,Guy Forsyth and Mary May Love, and others.

In 2015, we are excited to announce the following lineup of musicians:

January: Carter Beckworth

February: Walt Wilkins

March: Sam Baker (A local escape from SXSW)

April: Eliza Gilkyson

May: Ray Benson

Cost per month: $2,000



Our Pub Church

Parable is The Front Porch's experimental pub church. We've hosted at a number of Austin bars and venues over the years, and we're currently settled in the large party room at Scholz Garten, where we meet one Sunday evening per month. At Parable, it's okay to drink craft beer and eat the delicious food purveyed by our host, and its especially encouraged to talk about the things that matter to us. Each Parable features an interview with a great Austin thinker or doer and music from Dave Madden, our resident musical genius. Here is the Austin Statesman’s article on one of our recent gatherings.

NPR’s John Burnett leads our Parable conversations. We have had so many different shades of intellect influence and shape this innovative approach to  postmodern church-- music legend Ray Benson, rabbi and jazz activist Neil Blumofe, public advocate Tom Spencer, adventurer Nelson Guda, naturalist Victor Emanuel, Senator Kirk Watson, journalist Evan Smith, writer and filmmaker Turk Pipkin, and psychoanalyst and Episcopal priest J. Pittman McGehee have all sat on the Porch for Parable in the past. 

     Folks gather at Opal Divine's to hear from Turk Pipkin at Parable, Summer 2014

At heart, Parable is about table fellowship with sinner, saint, and outcast. As such, it is a reimagining of worship. We invite all people of any tradition to join us for food, conversation, and our special, open-to-all communion at our monthly pub church event.

Our Program for Young People

                                 

The Window provides a rare space for high school students and young adults where no idea is censured and individuality is encouraged. The Window seeks to  open up new perspectives for young people in an environment where fellowship created from the ground up, not the top down. Our newest program, The Window launched last September with a program designed by Mother Falcon guitarist and producer, Matt Puckett. Since then, we've also hosted Hideout improv guru, Andy Crouch, and rising Austin hip hop outfit, Magna Carda, as well as played a number of stimulating games that celebrate our differences in perspective and open up dialogue between the members of our growing youth community. Much as in Parable, our youth celebrate an open, religion-free communion at The Window-- usually pizza or something of the like-- in a symbolic feeding of our spiritual hunger and celebration of our community. Singer-songwriter Josh Dodds is our musical director. The event happens on Sunday evenings, twice monthly.

                                                                         Magna Carda at The Window, November 2014

Cost: $1,000 per month

What do we want from you?

We are asking friends, fellow risk-takers, and those who are moved by our vision to support us with funding. Here is a financial breakdown of the costs for funding six months of our twelve month 2015 season.

  • Elephant in the Room costs us somewhere around $3,000 per event. This number estimates costs for speaker, travel, lodging, venue, staffing, and advertising. Funding for Six Months: $6,000
  • Each Parable costs us about $1,000. Our excellent musicians and speakers, as well as staffing and occasional venue costs, make up the primary cost of this event. Funding for Six Months: $6,000
  • Unplugged on the Front Porch costs $2,000. Our top musicians, our sound team, our lighting team, our equipment costs, refreshments, and more make up the costs for this event. Funding for Six Months: $12,000
  • Each session of The Window costs roughly $500. Our speakers, musicians, staffing and refreshment costs make up this number. Funding for Six Months: $6,000
If you notice, that all adds up to exactly $30,000.

Every dollar over $30,000 gives us new choices. We always end up hosting a few events a year outside of the confines of our regular concerts and lecture series. We would also love to increase the frequency of each of these events. Ideally, any extra money would go immediately toward six more months of great Front Porch programs, building the rest of 2015.

Our Path--Past and Future

The Front Porch got its start in the year 2000, when Front Porch director Stephen Kinney and a group of close friends began reading deep into some heavy duty thinkers. Kinney writes of the early days:

"The small group of us who'd meet weekly...expanded to 10-25 people who'd read an article, discuss an idea, or explore the hermeneutic philosophy of thinkers like Wittgenstein, Gadamer, or Taylor. We talked about Colin Gunton's latest book on the Trinity as an idea for creating new life and understanding through dialogical friendships--a relational practice that got us beyond modern, abstract notions of truth and universal reason. 

We talked about stuff that had implications for how individuals lived well in wider community. Our...interdisciplinary approach meant we got into social theory and science, political perspectives, art and music. Connections between different ideas and perspectives were being made, evaluated, or reinterpreted. It was fun to think in what I'd call radically incarnational ways. The world opened up.

Other people became very important for the added perspectives they brought to the table and gave voice to. Calling "the other" into being, sharing a felt communion not in spite of but because of our differences was experienced. The idea of building our community through such personal interaction on multiple levels became an intention."

Now, over a decade later, The Front Porch has followed its dialogical path to unprecedented activity and influence. Our events are turning out bigger crowds, ranging anywhere from 50 to 200 people at any given gathering. As we look for new ways to keep larger groups engaged in our intimate, Front Porch ideal, we are excited to know that our ideologies are catching on and turning heads. The more people that join The Front Porch community, the better. Each new face gives us more and more reason to pursue our long term goal- the acquisition and implementation of our own permanent event space. Ideally, this space will be a pub/cafe with a venue stage where we could offer a year's worth of programming on The Front Porch, seven days a week. This is our dream for this project, the thing we are always working toward.

Risks/Challenges

What if we don't raise our whole goal? We'll carry on, of course. We will gratefully accept and put to frugal use all money we make from this campaign, our 2015 season poised to spring into action even if we don't get near the goal. Still, we hope that our message is compelling enough to earn your generosity.

Risks for The Front Porch are few, since we already have our programs in place. We know what to expect and how to plan them. If you like our ideas, you can expect us to implement them to perfection and with efficiency.

Our newest challenge lies in maintaining our spirit of intimate companionship and community in spite of our growing numbers. The more events we can sponsor, the better off we are in combating this, since it would increase everyone's immediate engagement with The Front Porch.

Another challenge lies in our limited scope. While some of our events are video taped and may reach a larger audience, the primary focus of The Front Porch is right here in Austin, Texas. Again, having a larger budget would help us produce more video content and allow us further opportunities to spread our message farther and wider than ever before.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're stretched right now, you could help us by getting more familiar with our events and programs and spreading the word about us to anyone you think might be interested. Especially share this Indiegogo opportunity with friends and enemies alike.
Remember, even a small donation will add up and be put to good use. Look at your yearly finances--if it looks like you'll owe money when you prepare your taxes, now is the time to get rid of that annoying excess by donating to this 501(c)(3) with a dream of crafting community and support through fellowship and open-minded love in Austin, Texas.

                           Darden Smith collaborates with The Front Porch to write a song. 2013

story:
Who are we?

We are a group of 14 youths (aged 18 to 26) from Singapore who one day decided to make good on our desire to take service learning beyond our privileged geographical contours. The social issues prevalent in India are vastly different from those we face in Singapore,  and thus we are embarking on this adventure to make friends with the people there, serve the community, and build sustainable relationships so as to drive long term positive change. 

We will be going to Manali and Delhi, places where we have existing local contacts, which would help greatly in facilitating our pioneering trip there.

'GO' stands for 'Global Outreach, and GO Projects is the umbrella under which our team initiates service trips to different parts of the world. GO India 2014 is the first of many future trips to India; in the past our members have embarked on GO Projects to other countries such as the Philippines. 

Why do we need your help?

As a pioneer project that is run and funded entirely by students, we are very much dependent on financial support. We will be working together with Youth With A Mission (YWAM) (http://ywamdelhi.com), a non-profit organisation already serving the needs of the Indian community and would be able to advise us on how we can serve alongside them. 

Some of the activities that we would be engaged in over there include:

  • Conducting a vacation school for children from the lower income community where we will be teaching them basic conversational English, Geography, Science, and Arts & Crafts
  • Painting a mural in Ashish Children's Home
  • Raising awareness of the ill effects of drug abuse as the consumption and trade of illegal drugs are huge social issues
  • Providing basic first aid and medical attention (e.g. bandaging, antiseptic, anti-inflammatory ointment etc) for people living in the slums of Delhi
  • Helping to feed malnourished children living in the slums
  • Christmas caroling and celebrations at various orphanages and senior citizens' homes to spread Christmas cheer
While some of us may live on a $30 weekly budget, many of the families in the slums are surviving on a $30 combined monthly family income.

How much?

We are looking to raise $5000 to cover our project costs, and purchase materials for the above programmes that we will be organizing. The more donations we receive, the more ambitious we can be with the scope of help we wish to render while we are in India.

We are immensely grateful for any amount you would like to donate.
story_txt:
Who are we?
We are a group of 14 youths (aged 18 to 26) from Singapore who one day decided to make good on our desire to take service learning beyond our privileged geographical contours. The social issues prevalent in India are vastly different
from those we face in Singapore,  and thus we are embarking on this adventure to make friends with the people there, serve the community, and build sustainable relationships so as to drive long term positive change. 
We will be going to Manali and Delhi, places where we have existing local contacts, which would help greatly in facilitating our pioneering trip there.
'GO' stands for 'Global Outreach, and GO Projects is the umbrella under which our team initiates service trips to different parts of the world. GO India 2014 is the
first of many future trips to India; in the past
our members have embarked on GO Projects to other countries such as the
Philippines. 
   
Why do we need your help?
As a pioneer project that is run and funded entirely by students, we are very much dependent on financial support. We will be working together with Youth With A Mission (YWAM) (http://ywamdelhi.com), a non-profit organisation already serving the needs of the Indian community and would be able to advise us on how we can serve alongside them. 
Some of the activities that we would be engaged in over there include:

Conducting a vacation school for children from the lower income community where we will be teaching them basic conversational English, Geography, Science, and Arts & Crafts
Painting a mural in Ashish Children's Home


Raising awareness of the ill effects of drug abuse as the consumption and trade of illegal drugs are huge social issues
Providing basic first aid and medical attention (e.g. bandaging, antiseptic, anti-inflammatory ointment etc) for people living in the slums of Delhi
Helping to feed malnourished children living in the slums

Christmas caroling and celebrations at various orphanages and senior citizens' homes to spread Christmas cheer

While some of us may live on a $30 weekly budget, many of the families in the slums are surviving on a $30 combined monthly family income.   How much?
 We are looking to raise $5000 to cover our project costs, and purchase materials for the above programmes that we will be organizing. The more donations we receive, the more ambitious we can be with the scope of help we wish to render while we are in India.
We are immensely grateful for any amount you would like to donate.

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
When Seychelles patchouli was the best in the world...

Back in 2003, patchouli could be found alongside roads and paths everywhere in the Seychelles. Few people know that until the early 1980's, the Seychelles was a major exporter of patchouli dried leaves (approx. 6 tons) and essential oil (460 tons) together with vanilla, The Seychelles patchouli used to be considered one of the best in the world because of its high content of patchouli alcohol (patchoulol) and the terpene Seychellene which has therapeutic and insect-repellent properties. 

The Globarom patchouli nursery humble beginnings

So imagine our shock when during a recent perfume workshop and olfactory field trip organised by our school  - The Perfumery Art School -  the hunt for patchouli on 3 of the main Seychelles islands left us empty handed! The tourism boom took place to the detriment of the patchouli plant, considered by the locals like a weed and therefore destroyed on every plot of land allocated for development! 

But a dedicated and passionate man, Mustafa Bristol, owner of Globarom (site under construction), the only distiller in the Seychelles. is so aware of the importance and the quality of the Seychelles patchouli that he has undertaken to revive it and place it back on the world map of precious botanical plants. Started in January 2014 with 10 plants 'rescued' from the forest, the  nursery now boasts 100 plants and counting.

The Perfumery Art School wants to help Mustafa 'save the Seychelles patchouli' and is working in close liaison with Andrea Butje, founder of Aromahead Institute in the USA and renowned supporter of distillers in the world. We are aiming to  raise $20000 to provide the first plants to the targeted families/farmers, expand the patchouli nursery and run the first patchouli distillation tests.

The Perfume Foundation International as the most active advocate for the rehabilitation of perfume plants worldwide is also supporting our common efforts in this exciting plant revival project.

Mustafa Bristol, owner and distiller, Globarom Seychelles

Some of the essential oils already distilled by Globarom 

June 2014 update

Look at how the patchouli nursery looks like now, one month after the launch of this campaign! Thanks to our generous contributors and supporters, the number of plants has now reached over 200!

The Globarom patchouli nursery 1 month after the launch of the campaign

Some facts about patchouli

Wherever you are in this world, you will probably have heard of patchouli! Apart from its ever association as THE perfume of the hippy movement, here are some interesting facts about its many virtues.  


Why we need your contribution?

The patchouli revival project not only involves regrowing the disappearing patchouli in the Seychelles. It is also aiming at creating new jobs in a more diversified economy, placing an emphasis on agriculture rather than on tourism only. Private individuals will be encouraged to grow patchouli in their gardens too.

We are initially targeting 100 Seychelles families/farmers. Each farmer will receive 10 plants at a cost of $74 spent on preparing and providing the patchouli plants to each family/farmer. Our time frame to secure a regular production for the essential oil distillation is 1 to 2 years depending on how soon the nursery is ready. 

The following is a detailed breakdown on where your contributions will go. With the exception of the fees identified in the chart, all funds will go directly towards the project. The Test & Certificates fees concern the testing of the patchouli oil and its certification (Ecocert, Organic) to be able to sell it internationally but will also contribute to the development of Globarom website.

How can you help?

In an ever more populated world, we need to focus on agricultural development but also to protect the plants of our Earth if they are to be sustained and benefit future generations. 

While our personal interest is to ensure the survival of a plant that is a major ingredient in most of the perfumes we wear, Research on the virtues of patchouli also shows that patchouli is important for its phytochemical and pharmalogical properties. Any attempt to create a synthetic version of patchouli has so far failed due to the complexity of its molecules.

Your contribution - even small -will help save and protect the Heritage of a symbolic plant and give a new impulse to this small archipelago in the middle of the Indian Ocean, the Seychelles. 

Our perks and their good vibes are sent to you with love, directly from the Seychelles to thank you for your generous support.

What if we don't raise the total amount?

In the patchouli revival project, any contribution is welcomed and will be used towards the expansion of the nursery. We would reduce the number of farmers we are planning to support to kick start the project and keep the momentum!

Patchouli grows quickly but its distillation requires drying the leaves for at least 24 hours in order to produce a quality essential oil.

Your contributions will also help us run the first distillation tests and have the oil quality tested.

The Team activists

Isabelle Gellé is the Founder of the Perfumery Art School, the first online vocational school in the Art of Perfumery offering certified course programs in traditional perfumery. She is also owner and perfumer of her own perfumery, Les Parfums d'Isabelle and since February 2014, the Chairperson of the Perfume Foundation for the Indian Ocean islands and Southern Africa, an international consumer organisation with a mission to protect the Heritage of perfumery and the sustainability of perfume plants.

Andrea Butje is the owner of Aromahead Institute, an an internationally recognized online Aromatherapy school. Andrea is changing the online educational paradigm through her inspired approach to teaching and creating community. She travels the world developing relationships with organic artisan distillers and developed the Distiller Database to connect distillers with essential oil companies.

Other Ways You Can Help

Patchouli not your thing! We understand you might not be able to contribute or might not be interested in patchouli, but you may be able to help by letting your friends know.

We ask the all supporters of our campaign to spread the ‘Help us revive the Seychelles patchouli’ message! 

Please help us ensure that the once best patchouli in the world makes its way back to the world map of essential oil production.

Thank you from Sesel (Seychelles in Creole)!

story:
Let's support TURC

The University Running Club, the coolest club on campus, now has the coolest alumni group!  Our goal is to create a group where former runners can stay in touch with other alumni as well as support the current team.  Our first official act will be to to help TURC get to Nationals!  

What we need

We all remember what it was like to be strapped for cash in college.  Coming up with the funds to carbo load is hard enough but throw on race fees and travel costs and running becomes downright expensive.  This year, the club expects to spend $6,000 to compete at Nationals in Michigan.  The Alumni group's goal is to raise a minimum of 10% or $600 to help get the team there.  Anything you can contribute will be greatly appreciated!

    The Impact

    Since its inception, TURC has always been a places where runners can come to meet new friends and share their joy for the sport.  Success for the club has always been measured participation - the more people the better.  In that tradition, the goal of this alumni fundraiser is to send the most people to nationals possible.  Achieving our goal is equivalent to sending 3 extra Minnesota runners to Nationals.

      Risks & Challenges

      We were a little slow to organize this year so timing is short!  We only have 1 week to complete this round so if you can participate, please do not delay.

        Other Ways You Can Help

        If you can't contribute, that doesn't mean you love TURC any less.  This is the first of many events and fundraisers - there will be plenty of additional ways to get involved in the future.  Stay in touch, cheer the team on, and keep running!

story:
Red Tails Race Team

Please join with The Palm Springs Air Museum and the Red Tails Race Team in the excitement of the most talked about and extraordinary air event ever, the National  Championship Air Races Reno. You will be helping us bring this rich history of the Tuskegee Airmen to a worldwide audience and over 150,000 people per day at the Races in person.

The Palm Springs Air Museum is one of the finest and most respected Air Museums in the world. For over twenty years bringing history alive with not only a wonderful collection of aircraft but also over 300 volunteers some who have stood on the beaches of Guadalcanal during World War II to those who have flown to the edges of Outer Space.

You will be part of the Red Tails Race Team and know that you played an important part as this gorgeous P-51 Mustang turns around the pylons with that engine roar that only comes from a P-51 Mustang! We are totally committed to the Race itself and your help will be going entirely to offset the expenses of this commitment. It is funded by the Palm Springs Air Museum which is a non-profit organization (Tax ID 33-0615350) and your participation helps greatly in allowing the Museum to continue it's core mission of bringing history and pride to the public it serves.

We are asking to raise $15,000 towards our our actual costs. Much of the staffing of this is being done by all volunteers who are taking on this project with incredible enthusiasm. But sadly enthusiasm alone will not pay for fuel, spare tires and engine parts, gas for vehicles, hotel rooms, food and so much more. So we really need you to be a part of our Team!

As a member of our Red Tails Race Team you get the fun stuff too! No question that the most sought after will be our Red Tails Race Team Crew Member T-Shirt! That will have "Bunny" on the back too! There are really cool Red Tails Race Team Dog Tags, Annual Air Museum Memberships, autographed Team Posters of "Bunny" signed by Tuskegee Airmen Captain Rusty Burns and  Lt. Col. Bob Friend. There is more too!

All monies raised will go to the project whether less or more than our goal. We are going to the Races! Your help means so much more too! It helps the Palm Springs Air Museum bring the history and excitement of aviation to groups of school children who visit during the year, it gives the Museum the ability to bring education and actual flying demonstrations on a weekly basis to our visitors and community, it allows the Museum to honor our Veterans by providing free entrance to them and their families and being a part of special programs. Your help from a little to a lot is very far reaching!

The Palm Springs Air Museum has built itself by accomplishing and meeting many goals. Recently completed is our Cold War Hangar dedicated to Major General Kenneth P. Miles. A modern 20,000 sq. ft. facility that we funded and built entirely from private donations! Then there is our recently completed Norman Lawrence Sirota D-Day Gliders Exhibit with an actual rebuild of one of the many ill-fated D-Day Gliders. Again all funded by the Museum from private donation. From our extensive and beautiful aircraft collection to our almost 10,000 volume library, the Palm Springs Air Museum is a testament to the responsible use of privately donated funding.

 “Bunny” is ready! Our top mechanics will be on hand with spare parts and the know how. She will be flown by one of the most experienced pilots in the business, a person who has been "Bunny's" pilot all along and knows her well. 

We know some some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Please get the word out for us!
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Share us on Social Media, Facebook or whatever is your favorite.
  • Like and watch the Facebook page for the Palm Springs Air Museum.

Share the excitement of the 2017 National  Championship Air Races Reno with us! That truly means so very much too! Thank You!

story:
Onion River Outdoors: The door to Onion River Sports may have closed, but a new door is about to open.

Having supported a locally-owned bike and ski shop for 43 years, Montpelier, VT understands the value of an outdoor gear store and appreciates how it greatly enhances the downtown economy, while enriching the local community. Onion River Sports may be gone, but we know Montpelier wants its hometown bike and gear store back, and with the help of generous souls like you, Kip and Jen Roberts are going to make it happen. Just in time for bike season, Onion River Outdoors will open in May, 2018 in the same familiar space on historic Langdon St. in Montpelier, VT that had been occupied by Onion River Sports since 1974. It will be a busy first few "soft opening" weeks, with two big events on the calendar: the Muddy Onion Gravel Ride on April 28th and the Montpelier Bike Swap on May 5th. With your help, we'll get off to a strong start and will be back to the business of serving central Vermonters with their outdoor service and gear needs!

What Will Be Familiar

  • A welcoming, family-friendly outdoor shop offering quality gear and apparel for active outdoor adventures, including bikes (mountain, gravel, commuter, fat, all-road, hybrid, and lots of kids' bikes!), camping and hiking gear, footwear, cross country and backcountry skis, snowshoes and sleds, casual and active outdoor apparel, yoga gear, and tons of fun accessories
  • Top-notch bicycle and ski service and the absolute best customer service anywhere
  • A strong commitment to community involvement through charitable giving and hosting events that draw folks from all over New England, such as the Montpelier Bike Swap, the Muddy Onion Spring Classic Gravel Ride, Dam Wrightsville Cyclocross Race, the Apple Grinder Fall Group Ride, the Independence Day Parade Clunker Bike Brigade, our popular film nights at the Savoy Theater, and more. Check out where we came from and where we're headed on our Facebook page!
  • Weekly group mountain bike and gravel rides for riders of all levels, as well as our ever-popular women’s rides
  • Focused running selection. Central Vermont has a lot of runners and ORO is proud to carry on the close relationship with Central Vermont Runners and all our junior, senior, competitive, and lunchtime runner friends
  • Seasonal bike and ski service clinics
  • PARTIES
  • Supporting and partnering with local outdoor organizations including MAMBA, CTA, VTBC, VMBA, and GMC to bolster their efforts for access to outdoor recreation

What Will Be New

  • Used gear sales. Due to popular demand (and Kip's and many of our staffs' affinity for uniquely-crafted, one-of-a-kind used bike builds), ORO will be buying, selling, and trading quality used hardgoods, gear, and outdoor apparel 
  • Commuter, cargo, and adventure E-Bike sales. E-bikes (electric, power-assisted bikes) are one of the fastest growing categories in the bike industry. Montpelier's challenging topography, bikeable downtown shopping district, and adventure just up and out of town lend themselves to the increased ability and mobility afforded by E-bikes
  • Kids gear and apparel. To fill the void left with the closing of Onion River Kids, ORO will carry an expanded selection of gear, shoes, and apparel for active kids
  • The Rusty Hub Lounge. Kick back after your run or ride in our lounge area and grab soul-warming cup of 802 Coffee and a local donut. Take a break: you deserve it

Who We Are

Kip and Jen Roberts and their 8-year-old daughter Indy will be putting the "family" into family-owned business and family-focused gear. Kip and Jen will be the proprietors of Onion River Outdoors and plan on running the business until Indy takes over in 20-30 years. Until then, here's a bit more info about Indy's parents.

Jen Roberts has devoted her life to outdoor recreation and to protecting our natural resources for future generations to enjoy. As Trail Director of Northern Forest Canoe Trail, she played an integral role in establishing the amazing 740 mile paddling route between Quebec and New York and edited the 13-map series and guidebook. She researched and wrote the book AMC’s Best Day Hikes in Vermont, (including the soon-to-be-released 2nd Edition), and most recently worked for Vermont Works For Women as Director of Girls’ Programs, overseeing several programs such as Dirt Divas and Rosie's Girls, which help girls develop grit, connection, and expanded possibilities. Jen is a mountain biker, former US Telemark Ski Team skier, paddler, hiker, and outdoor enthusiast.

Kip Roberts: Any regular customer of Onion River Sports knows Kip well. Kip worked at Onion River Sports from 2002 until it closed, and when he wasn’t standing on the podium at the end of The Race To The Top of Vermont or a regional cyclocross race, Kip was Onion River’s General Manager, hardgoods buyer, and ride leader for the weekly group mountain bike, fat bike, and gravel bike rides. Kip is an avid cyclist and skier, a die-hard, any-weather bike commuter, and a passionate advocate for outdoor recreation and inclusive trail expansion.

What We Need and What You Get 

We are starting from scratch, so we need to raise a significant amount of money, plain and simple. We've already pulled together a number of pieces to create a workable financing package, but more is needed and we're reaching out to our friends in the community assist. Please help us get the word out by sharing our campaign through your various social networks, and please pledge whatever amount you can afford--and remember, contributions over $200 receive a 1-to-1 match in ORO purchasing power, so you're essentially prebuying some sweet new gear! One of the most common reasons that small business startups struggle is due to undercapitalization and we are determined to avoid that! Our goal is to raise $85K through this campaign which is less than a fourth of what we ultimately need to help with the following costs:

  • Infrastructure and hardware: Over 40 years of business has taken a toll and the space is in need of updates. Although we plan on staying on the frugal side, we do want to give the space a fresh look and feel. Computers/Point of Sale upgrades, phones, tools, efficient lighting upgrades--there's a laundry list!
  • Inventory: Hands down our biggest expense, we have nearly 4000 square feet of retail space to fill with inventory and because we're a start-up, we need money up front to get product from our vendors
  • Other Costs: Rent, insurance, payroll, advertising, staff training, and lots more
  • Emergency Fund: Unexpected costs are a given, so we need to make sure we have money set aside to cover them if and when they come up

Aside from our deepest gratitude and the personal satisfaction of directly helping us reopen and getting back to the business of promoting healthy lifestyles and engaging the community through sales, service, and events we're offering fabulous perks for everyone who donates. Contribute $200 or more and redeem those Onion Bucks 1-for-1 at ORO starting June 1st! Check out available perks on the right hand side of the page.
story_txt:
Onion River Outdoors: The door to Onion River Sports may have closed, but a new door is about to open.Having supported a locally-owned bike and ski shop for 43 years, Montpelier, VT understands the value of an outdoor gear store and appreciates how it greatly enhances the downtown economy, while enriching the local community. Onion River Sports may be gone, but we know Montpelier wants its hometown bike and gear store back, and with the help of generous souls like you, Kip and Jen Roberts are going to make it happen. Just in time for bike season, Onion River Outdoors will open in May, 2018 in the same familiar space on historic Langdon St. in Montpelier, VT that had been occupied by Onion River Sports since 1974. It will be a busy first few "soft opening" weeks, with two big events on the calendar: the Muddy Onion Gravel Ride on April 28th and the Montpelier Bike Swap on May 5th. With your help, we'll get off to a strong start and will be back to the business of serving central Vermonters with their outdoor service and gear needs!What Will Be Familiar
A welcoming, family-friendly outdoor shop offering quality gear and apparel for active outdoor adventures, including bikes (mountain, gravel, commuter, fat, all-road, hybrid, and lots of kids' bikes!), camping and hiking gear, footwear, cross country and backcountry skis, snowshoes and sleds, casual and active outdoor apparel, yoga gear, and tons of fun accessories
Top-notch bicycle and ski service and the absolute best customer service anywhere
A strong commitment to community involvement through charitable giving and hosting events that draw folks from all over New England, such as the Montpelier Bike Swap, the Muddy Onion Spring Classic Gravel Ride, Dam Wrightsville Cyclocross Race, the Apple Grinder Fall Group Ride, the Independence Day Parade Clunker Bike Brigade, our popular film nights at the Savoy Theater, and more. Check out where we came from and where we're headed on our Facebook page!
Weekly group mountain bike and gravel rides for riders of all levels, as well as our ever-popular women’s rides
Focused running selection. Central Vermont has a lot of runners and ORO is proud to carry on the close relationship with Central Vermont Runners and all our junior, senior, competitive, and lunchtime runner friends
Seasonal bike and ski service clinics
PARTIES
Supporting and partnering with local outdoor organizations including MAMBA, CTA, VTBC, VMBA, and GMC to bolster their efforts for access to outdoor recreation
What Will Be New
Used gear sales. Due to popular demand (and Kip's and many of our staffs' affinity for uniquely-crafted, one-of-a-kind used bike builds), ORO will be buying, selling, and trading quality used hardgoods, gear, and outdoor apparel 
Commuter, cargo, and adventure E-Bike sales. E-bikes (electric, power-assisted bikes) are one of the fastest growing categories in the bike industry. Montpelier's challenging topography, bikeable downtown shopping district, and adventure just up and out of town lend themselves to the increased ability and mobility afforded by E-bikes
Kids gear and apparel. To fill the void left with the closing of Onion River Kids, ORO will carry an expanded selection of gear, shoes, and apparel for active kids
The Rusty Hub Lounge. Kick back after your run or ride in our lounge area and grab soul-warming cup of 802 Coffee and a local donut. Take a break: you deserve it
Who We AreKip and Jen Roberts and their 8-year-old daughter Indy will be putting the "family" into family-owned business and family-focused gear. Jen is a mountain biker, former US Telemark Ski Team skier, paddler, hiker, and outdoor enthusiast.Kip Roberts: Any regular customer of Onion River Sports knows Kip well. Kip worked at Onion River Sports from 2002 until it closed, and when he wasn’t standing on the podium at the end of The Race To The Top of Vermont or a regional cyclocross race, Kip was Onion River’s General Manager, hardgoods buyer, and ride leader for the weekly group mountain bike, fat bike, and gravel bike rides. Kip is an avid cyclist and skier, a die-hard, any-weather bike commuter, and a passionate advocate for outdoor recreation and inclusive trail expansion.What We Need and What You Get We are starting from scratch, so we need to raise a significant amount of money, plain and simple. story:
First, a Thank You Note:

We want to thank everyone who supported and believed in us last fall before we even served a single hot dog! We want to thank every single customer who came and gave us a chance. We want to thank our business partners who support us. We've tried hard to return the favor with great food and great community service! 

You are all special to us, and you have our sincere and eternal gratitude for your kindness, assistance and encouragement. We trust that you have had a positive experience and enjoyed the great food and service we have offered to this point.

Here's the Deal:

We opened in January, thanks to the help of many Indiegogo funders!

We need your help to stay open!

Our goal of donating 100% of our profits is hampered by the fact that we have not YET reached profitability...HOWEVER...our RoundUP Program has put almost $6000 back in the local community in just 9 months!! Imagine what we can do in the future!!!

Why we need your help again:

  • Operating costs held over from the old brand (Easton locals know what I'm talking about) cut into our funds for startup of the NEW, GOOD brand!
  • Personal issues have limited our ability as owners to work as much as possible, and to contribute our own funds to the operation.

Where we are now:

The response from the community and customers has been overwhelmingly positive. People genuinely love the variety of fun food we serve, and are very supportive of the service we have tried to provide for the local causes.

We think our concept, business model and product are unique in the market, and can be sustainable in the long term. At this point, however, we may be unable to continue operations without a significant investment, so closing our doors might be the only option.

We are now asking our fans and loyal customers to let us know how you feel! If you like us and want to see us continue to serve great food and do good work in the community, let us know with a donation.

"Almost there.....almost there" --Garven Dreis, Red Leader 

What we will use your $ for:

Operating costs (50% of it). Working towards profitability, but not there yet.

Advertising (25% of it). Somehow people in our small town don't know we exist yet. Hard to believe but true. People outside the county are really unaware. Poor souls.

Facility / Equipment (25% of it). The old gal needs some work - floors, ceilings, etc, and we'd love to buy some catering equipment to take the dogs to you!

percentages are approximate

AND MOST IMPORTANTLY : WHAT YOU GET FOR YOUR $

Some of our delicious food for FREE

and every donor over $25 gets to paint a tile for our ever-growing "Wall of Fun"  (name of wall is subject to change). 

So if you like us, show us! If only 1/2 of our social media fans and followers donate $25 each we will reach our goal and continue to provide great food and great community service!

story:
"There was no difference between men, in intelligence or race, so profound as the difference between the sick and the well."

 

WHAT'S THE PROBLEM?

In 2007, I was a producer for ABC News and will never forget having lived inside Johns Hopkins Hospital for four months.  I followed and filmed the lives of surgeons and patients, whose paths cross unlike any other human relationship I've seen.  And yet always interrupted by a system beyond their control, I could understood why both brimmed with frustration at times.  But I took note – nothing put their minds at ease quite like a clear, honest explanation or a simple human gesture.

Education was key.  And that's why our campaign aims to grow a more open, unbiased online space for increasingly web-reliant surgeons and patients to better learn from each other.  It's about time.  

Since 2009, I've aggressively pursued my interests in online content, and apparently so have patients.  75% of all American adults went online in search of health information, but 86% of them preferred to consult with a more trusted doctor.  And when 30 million of those Americans are patients about to undergo surgery every year, the information online that has the power to put minds at ease should not be so hard to navigate, to trust, and to understand.

I asked myself: Was it possible to find surgeons, who were willing to utilize the web for future generations, but as an independent collective, wanting nothing more than to better educate, guide, and inspire all patients, both privileged and not? 

Seven world-class heart surgeons stepped forward. And so the Open Clinic was born.

 

WHAT IS THE OPEN CLINIC? 

Open Clinic is a website for any patient who wants to learn about heart surgery directly from a band of seven world-class heart surgeons located throughout the United States. These young surgeons of the Open Clinic are all equipped with web cameras so that they can easily self-publish their own video answers to general questions about surgery that site users submit.

We’re also a 501(c)(3) non-profit on a mission to build the most unbiased and accessible patient education experience online for every type of surgical patient. Highly literate or not, English-speaking or not, even lacking direct Internet access or not, it doesn’t matter. Open Clinic is designed with these differences in mind from the very start.

What we’re not is important to note. Open Clinic is not an e-consult service where patients can get specific diagnoses or medical advice. Open Clinic is not here to market doctors. Open Clinic is not here to replace clinic visits, but to supplement them in a way that feels human and much like the real thing, so that in-person clinic visits can have more quality time.

 

WHY DO WE NEED FUNDING?

For over two years, we’ve built Open Clinic in our free time from an idea to a working online platform and non-profit organization. We're a team of volunteers, having funded everything out of our own pocket, and while the surgeons of the Open Clinic will generously continue to volunteer their time and medical expertise to Open Clinic, we’ve now reached a point where a little money can go a very long way.

If you can help us reach our goal of $15K, then we'll use those funds for:

  • Grow the Open Clinic for other major heart surgeries: 1) Coronary Angioplasty & Stenting, 2) Mitral Valve Repair/Replacement, 3) Aortic Valve Repair/Replacement, 4) Aortic Aneurysm Surgery, 5) Atrial Fibrillation Surgery

  • Promotion and outreach out to potential partners (patient organizations, physician societies, public libraries, non-medical corporate sponsors)

  • Web hosting, site maintenance, and Spanish and Mandarin Chinese translations of the Open Clinic for one year

If we're able to make our 1st stretch goal of $30K, then we'll use the extra funds to launch Open Clinic for Women's Health Surgery and similarly help all women about to undergo gynecologic and breast cancer surgery.

If we're able to make our 2nd stretch goal of $60K, then we'll use the extra funds to recruit a talented staff member whose passion for business development can take Open Clinic to the next level as a non-profit organization.

 

WHAT DO YOU GET IN RETURN?

"If you have built castles in the sky, your work need not be lost.  That is where they should be.  Now, put the foundations under them," said Henry David Thoreau and as such, we wonder: what if your contributions could literally be the foundations under the Open Clinic, our floating clinic in the cloud?

With any contribution level you choose, the amount will correspond to the size of a virtual 'brick', which we'll use to assemble a digital model of the Open Clinic based on your everyone's bricks.  We have no idea what the final rendering will look like until this campaign is over, but brick by brick, we'll have built together a new kind of clinic in more ways than one.

$5

We’ll send you a wholehearted "thank you" email and you'll also receive a '5' brick added in your name to our digital model of the Open Clinic.

$10 
You'll receive a '10' brick added in your name to our digital model of the Open Clinic. Plus, you'll receive a high-quality digital poster of the final rendering of Open Clinic as built by all of our backers' bricks. 

$25
You'll receive a '25' brick added in your name to our digital model of the Open Clinic and also a high-quality digital poster of the final rendering of Open Clinic as built by all of our backers' bricks. Plus, we'll send you a unique, double-ended red pen and custom Open Clinic notebook, each page beautifully designed as a checklist to help you to transform your thoughts into action, one to-do at a time. 

 

$50
You'll receive a '50' brick added in your name to our digital model of the Open Clinic and also a high-quality digital poster of the final rendering of Open Clinic as built by all of our backer’ bricks. Plus, we'll mail you a physical version of any one of the four transformative works that have inspired Open Clinic along the way, in hopes that it may inspire you as well:

    • Self Renewlal by John W. Gardner

    • The Once and Future King by T.H. White

    • Seven Samurai by Akira Kurosawa

    • Better by Atul Gawande, MD

$100
With this gift, you'll help us to launch Open Clinic for all patients of the following major cardiovascular surgeries:

    • Coronary artery bypass grafting

    • Coronary stenting and angioplasty

    • Mitral valve repair/replacement

    • Aortic valve repair/replacement

    • Aortic aneurysm surgery

    • Atrial fibrillation surgery

We also want to publicly thank you on the Open Clinic website, where our entire community will find your name in a dedicated “Special Supporters” section for any one of the heart surgeries you may choose above.  You'll get a '100' brick that we'll add in your name to our digital model of the Open Clinic, and of course, feel free to pick any one of the gifts above.

$500 
With this gift, you’ll help us to launch Spanish and Mandarin Chinese versions of Open Clinic for a global audience. We'll list your name on the Open Clinic website in a dedicated "Special Ambassadors" section and do a feature profile of you for our Spanish or Mandarin users. And yes, you'll get the biggest '500' brick added in your name to our digital model of the Open Clinic along with any one of the gifts above.

 

 

$1,000 (12 spots) 
With this gift, we’ll present you as the sole sponsor for an entire month of the Open Clinic for Heart Surgery. There are only 12 spots available for organizations interested in integrating your brand into our site in an elegant way. (Sorry, but we can’t accept any medical companies.)  

If you're an individual, we'll do a special profile of you for our entire cardiovascular community, publicly announce you as one of the “Founding Patrons” of the Open Clinic for Heart Surgery, and of course, feel free to pick any one of the gifts above.

 

WHO ARE WE, EXACTLY?

Kenneth Chu is the founder and Executive Director of Open Clinic. As a former ABC News producer of the Peabody Award-winning medical documentary series Hopkins, he is currently a producer for NBC News Digital.

Chad Ellimoottil, MD is the Deputy Director of Open Clinic. As a surgical resident at Loyola University Medical Center in Chicago, Illinois, his research interests include the cost-effectiveness of healthcare and the quality of patient education online.

Alexandra Lee is the Development Director of Open Clinic. She currently works in communications for the humanitarian organization Doctors Without Borders, and has previously managed fundraising campaigns for the arts.

John Doty, MD is the Medical Director of Open Clinic and a cardiovascular surgeon at Intermountain Medical Center in Salt Lake City, Utah. He did all of his training at Johns Hopkins Hospital. 

Torin Fitton, MD is a Founding Surgeon of Open Clinic and a cardiovascular surgeon at The Lahey Clinic in Burlington, Massachusetts. He did all of his training at Johns Hopkins Hospital. 

Richard Lee, MD is a Founding Surgeon of Open Clinic and a cardiovascular surgeon at St.Louis University Hospital in St. Louis, Missouri. He trained at Rush University, Washington University, and the Cleveland Clinic.

Leora Balsam, MD is a Founding Surgeon of Open Clinic and a cardiovascular surgeon at New York University Medical Center in New York City. She did all of her training at Stanford University.

Cullen Morris, MD is a Founding Surgeon of Open Clinic and a cardiovascular surgeon at The Emory Clinic in Athens, Georgia. He trained at Emory University and the Texas Heart Institute. 

Chris Malaisrie, MD is a Founding Surgeon of Open Clinic and a cardiovascular surgeon at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago, Illinois. He trained at Loyola University, Baylor College, and Stanford University. 

Fardad Esmailian, MD is a Founding Surgeon of Open Clinic and a cardiovascular surgeon at Cedars-Sinai Medical Institute in Los Angeles, California. He trained at UC-San Diego and UCLA. 

The current Open Clinic website was generously built by PJ Kelly and Joe Steele (software development); Lisa Maya (site design) and Michael Yuan (logo design); Tanya Northfield (medical transcriptions), Lucero Diaz (Spanish translations) and Sharon Chen (Mandarin Chinese translations).

 

WHAT HAVE WE ALREADY DONE?

We’ve launched the "Lite" version of Open Clinic to focus on coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) – the most commonly performed heart surgery in America, affecting men and women equally. CABG patients who enter the Open Clinic website can currently:

  • Find every answer as a video of a surgeon giving a very clear explanation

  • Browse an organized, easy-to-navigate library of 23 surgeon video answers, totaling to over 30 minutes of personal education coming straight from multiple heart surgeons

  • Read text transcripts of all surgeon video answers

  • Discover new questions to ask, as submitted by other real patients

  • Submit your own question for an Open Clinic surgeon video answer

  • Watch a video animation that walks through each procedure step-by-step

  • Reference easy-to-understand medical definitions and diagrams

  • Experience iPad-friendly versions of all surgeon video answers

 

In addition, we’ve also achieved a lot as a non-profit organization:

  • Partnered with a public library in a low-income Chicago neighborhood

  • Received a 501(c)(3) tax-exempt status from the IRS

  • Engaged by Gibson, Dunn, & Crutcher for pro-bono corporate legal work

  • Engaged by Manatt, Phelps, & Phillips for pro-bono healthcare legal work

  • Translated all CABG patient questions and surgeon video answers into Spanish and Mandarin Chinese for their underserved communities

 

WHAT MAJOR IMPACT CAN WE MAKE? 

As our population ages and becomes more culturally diverse, imagine a day in the future when all patients about to undergo surgery can have the Open Clinic always by their side.

As medicine advances, imagine how many new patient questions there will be to ask, filter through, and truly understand. But also imagine new generations of young surgeons inspired to continue in their own way what the Founding Surgeons of Open Clinic have begun.

One specialty at a time…

One language at a time…

HOW ELSE CAN YOU HELP?

We’re actively seeking other individuals, organizations, and brands who would like to forge some very creative and impactful relationships. Let’s talk about how we can work together and really improve publishing of health information online: alexandra.lee@openclinic.com

Also, feel free to check out our special updates and content on Twitter, Facebook, or our Open Clinic Notes newsletter.

And without a doubt, we understand that people's attention is hard to come by, so even if you can share this with someone who might be interested in what we're up to, then we'd truly appreciate it.
